title: 114_s278
content: The "Citizen Empowerment Act" may be cited as the official title. Part III of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding a new chapter 79A for services to members of the public. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" establishes procedures for in-person and telephonic interactions by executive branch employees regarding possible violations of federal statutes or regulations. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" defines terms like violation, State, and telephonic. It also requires the recording of enforcement actions by individuals. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" allows individuals to make audio recordings of interactions with Executive agency employees at their own expense. Employees conducting interactions can also record with prior notification to the individual. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" permits individuals and Executive agency employees to record interactions, with employees required to inform individuals before recording and provide a transcript upon request with reimbursement for costs. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" requires Executive agency employees to inform individuals of their rights before any covered interaction, with separate notifications needed for separate violations. This also applies to official representatives or those holding power. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" allows official representatives to make audio recordings of covered interactions conducted by Executive agency employees and receive transcripts or copies of the recordings. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" allows official representatives to receive transcripts or copies of audio recordings of covered interactions conducted by Executive agency employees, with the same rights and notice as the individual involved. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" grants individuals the right to own any audio recordings or transcripts made under the act. It does not establish a private right of action and includes exceptions for discussions involving classified material. The section excludes covered interactions involving classified material, information endangering public safety, or ongoing criminal investigations by federal law enforcement officers. The Law Enforcement Congressional Badge of Bravery Act of 2008 excludes certain interactions involving classified material, public safety risks, or ongoing criminal investigations by federal law enforcement officers. Employees must notify individuals of exceptions to audio recording permissions. The section requires making audio recordings of specific interactions and supersedes certain laws related to recording covered interactions. Violations will result in disciplinary action for Executive agency employees. Violations will result in disciplinary action for Executive agency employees. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the analysis for part III of title 5, United States Code. The section 79A pertains to services provided to the public, specifically under code 7921.
